we used post-erata rules for how the Permanency spell worked
it used to be something like "Multiply the level of the spell times 1000 Gold" for the components of the spell
it basically let you make any spell last "forever"
so long as it had a duration above instant
we abused this by using it on Level 0 spells! Because 0 x 1000 Gold is 0 Gold!
But level 0 spells arent like super fancy - but there was one that had so many uses-
that's when the you get hit with a random piano falling from the heavbens
I would presume spells didn't start till level 1.
no one knows where it came from, but now you'Re dead
level 0 spells are weak spells that don't cost a spell slot and thus can be cast infinite time without having to rest
back then you still had limited 0 level spells

Well, I found out that an artist I adopted a character from has some strict restrictions on what you can and cannot do with the adopted character.  Plus her rules apply to custom design characters too.  I can understand her reasoning though.
It's to prevent people from buying a cheap adopt and then making a bunch of money off the character.
I've always been a little confused about adoptables.
I understand the concept of purchasing the usage of a character design.
But if I were going to pay money for it, I'd want full rights to it.

Yeah I know what you mean, but it's also because she doesn't want people to adopt a character and then kill them off in some sort of gore fetish.  Most artists I adopt characters from do allow me to use the design and character.  She's the first though.

And the rules are to prevent people from using the character for other fetishes since she's mainly a strict clean artist.  She got into trouble when a potential employer spotted a character she had sold to another person.  That other person had
sex artwork done of that character which was a bit awkward for her.
Explaining to her employer about this.
So, I can see it both ways.  It's a good compromise but it does limit the buyer's usage of the character.  I mean I have no intention of using it for some gore fetish or anything like that
But I would like to use the character in stories that I plan to write.  The thing is I can't sell or publish the stories.  Well, I can publish the stories just not profit from the stories.

So, if a publisher sees the stories and wants to publish the story I can't.  Although the artist I adopted the character from did say she was willing to sell a license to me to allow me to use the design based on how many books I plan on selling.
And she's flexible to even take a very small cut of the royalties.
Instead of charging me everytime I use the character.
I can have artwork done of the character, give them a backstory, feature them in stories, etc. I just can't make any money off the adopted character.
But yeah, Tom you are right it is a bit confusing.
Don't get me wrong, she's an awesome and excellent artist.

And I'm not belittling her in any way.  It's just a bit surprised as I assumed she was talking about selling pictures of the adopted character, although I should had checked to see if her TOS included stories as well.  But she's very reasonable
according to those who have done business with her.
It is a very lucrative business actually.  I've seen people willing to pay over a $1000 for a single character.
Although that was only one time since it was an auction and the bidding got way out of hand.
But you are right though.  I would prefer to purchase the full rights to the character.
Hmm...never even knew tgat was a thing really.
you do get full rights to the character you adpoted
Not always Blue.  It depends on the artist and their terms of service.
Most artists do though.  But there are a few who still own the design.  You own the character but not the design.
It is a good idea since it prevents people from taking credit for something you designed for.
Oh well I have adopted a few characters myself.  I bough those that sell the full rights too you
The vast majority I bought from do give me the full rights.  It's just one artist I bought from.  But being a business major I have to look at it from both sides of the fence.
But yeah Vat, selling adoptable characters is a big thing.  Some people make a living off of it.
It's the same way that Fluff-Kevlar depends on his Patreon account to pay his bills and buy his groceries.
Oh there was one adoptable that sold for 4k
Wow!  Yeah like I said selling adoptables is quite lucrative.
that one was a type of Dragon though. Vary nice detail
Nods.  Dragons, especially detailed ones, are usually popular as well as anything canine or feline related.  Cheetah adopts usually go quickly.  I blame Mihari for that.  ;P
I know a person that dose custom Adopts for $15. But I bought 3 cheetahs and well due to the spots cost me about $40
I see.  Who is that if you don't mind asking?
oh hold on I can send you a linl
Hm... I've seen some artists for money can add OC to their comics. Of course not as main character. I wonder how much it will be cost to add OC in TK. I think it will be a gigantic pile of cash.
BTW the $15 custom adoptable isn't like the highest quality but it gets the base down right.

Cool.  Do you own the design of the character as well, or does the artist?  Can you do whatever you want with the character afterwards (although I actually would never kill off any adoptable character I get, even the bad guys).
He uses a base from someone else. BUT its yours and do what ever you want with them. Never saw in his rules he owns a part of it
Ah I see.  Well, that's good to hear.
Yup, artist to artist and contract to contract.
It's all copyright divisions and agreements.
I guess you're saying that it varies from artist to artist right @Dadrobit
The original artist holds the rights to Reproduction, Distrobution, and Derivitaves of the original.
I mean I don't see my characters I bought for $15 commissions so I take they are fully mine
Yeah that law gets mentioned lot in cases of copyright infringement involving anime fansubs.
Any of those "bundle of rights" that the original copyright holder has can be negotiated for in the "adoption".
It's really just that you're purchasing a liscense to use the character.
Fairly well within their rights to deny the usage for explicit stuff if it's discussed prior.
Indeed.  The big thing is to prevent hoarders from adopting the characters and to keep gore fetishers from adopting the character and killing them off never to be used again.
And it's a good way to keep clean artists safe as they probably don't want people to associate them with adult art.
yeah Well I have adopted characters for a story I am writing... r-r BUT some may die off. I have a few I will use for other projects
Eh, I mean I get it and I support their decision. But I also don't get why it's such a big deal of "not being associated with X fetish," over "don't make unauthorized revenue from this."
The fetish art might use the same character, but it's going to be associated with a completely different artist.

I mean they'll probably die off of old age or off screen or something.  Well, Dadrobit I know sometimes people have sold characters that have already been named and sometimes someone might say this fetish artwork uses a character I adopted from so and so
Going around making $ without paying royalties, that's what would irk me tbh.
Yeah, I would make sure to ask about royalties with an artist whose design I use.
I wish there was actual data on cases where a character adoption being used "distastefully" triggered backlash against the original artist.
I seriously doubt there's a impactful effect on the original artists revenue form people going "ew, I saw what happened to one of their other adoptions."
Yeah, that's true.  I guess they want to cover their bases prior to something going wrong.  A way to heading off any trouble that might or may happen in the future.
I mean, maybe there is, but I really doubt it.
I think it's the hoarding and the gore fetish that I've seen are the two big factors in those contracts.
As well as the not giving credit where's credit is due too
